conclusion: Determine horizontal and vertical accelerations using kinematic equations.
Initial velocity of the missile is 0 m/s.
Initial height of the missile is 20000 m.
Acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/s^2.
Missile accelerates uniformly upward with acceleration 10g until altitude 5000 m.
Vertical displacement equation: h = h_0 + 1/2 at^2.
Substitute values into vertical displacement equation: 5000 = 20000 + 5t^2.
Solve for t^2: t^2 = -3000.
Calculate t: t = sqrt(-3000) = 50sqrt(3) m/s.
Missile follows a curved trajectory until it hits the enemy aircraft.
Direction of gas expulsion changes to angle θ (cosθ = 1/11) downward and to the right.
Horizontal displacement equation: x = v_0t + 1/2 at^2.
Substitute values into horizontal displacement equation: x = 0 + 12500sqrt(3).
Calculate horizontal displacement: x = 12500sqrt(3) m.
Missile hits the enemy aircraft at height 20000 m.
Missile's mass is 100 kg.
Horizontal displacement equation: x = v_0t + 1/2 at^2.
Substitute values into horizontal displacement equation: x = 0 + 12500sqrt(3).
Calculate horizontal displacement: x = 12500sqrt(3) m.
Vertical displacement equation: h = h_0 + 1/2 at^2.
Substitute values into vertical displacement equation: h = 20000 + 12500sqrt(3).
Calculate vertical displacement: h = 20000 + 12500sqrt(3).
Calculate horizontal acceleration: a_x = 250 m/s^2.
